content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I did a on a possible tricky way to solve all tests cases, but the creator of this clash thought about everything.

Looking forward to finish my solution and explore how other persons did it.

I like the problem, will do soon and publish my solution !!
Nice One !

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I like the idea and it is suitable for a clash in my opinion.

Suggest to include width (length of each line) as an input, or at least mention that all lines of the grid are of the same length in Constraints section.

Thanks.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice clash and any issues with it's solvability in Reverse mode have been fixed with added test cases.

This is cool, but I think it's very hard and a bit ambiguous for Reverse. (It's currently only enabled for Reverse mode, but you have a statement, which is not recommended for Reverse, is this meant to be Fastest?)

This took me 10 minutes under Reverse conditions. It was easy enough to get the idea, but I coded for rectangle at one point assuming they would be tested, but realised it's only ever 'squares', 'triangles' or 'round shapes'.

I think this would be hard enough even with the full statement. I think most clashers would struggle to differentiate between round and triangle under time constraints.

It is solvable in 5 minutes though if you see the simplest pattern to differentiate them straight away. I'd approve this for Fastest and Shortest, but I think it's a bit ambiguous for Reverse, unless you add more test cases to make it clear that rectangles won't appear and also that [[n]] will always be greater than 1. [[n]] = 1 would of course be an evil edge case for which there is no wrong answer really. It's best to have the statement so that clasher's can be assured of the scope of the problem. :)

Hi! Thanks for your thorough comment!

Just to be clear, are you saying that you saw the testcases had only "square", "triangle" and "round", but you still implemented rectangle just in case I had a hidden validator with "rectangle"?

I added Fastest and Shortest but I'm a bit sad at the idea of removing Reverse.

Yeah, basically that's what happened yeah.

If you add some extra test cases, Reverse could be ok, it's just always good to have more tests for Reverse so that the pattern is easier to confidently detect.

I added four test cases. Now there are in total:
3 squares
5 triangles
3 rounds

Nice. Seems good to me now, but you really should remove the statement, so that would-be approvers can evaluate it as a Reverse puzzle, since you've got it enabled for Reverse only.

People usually just write the word "Reverse" for each section of the statement.
Cool, Shortest mode will be fun.
